Description: Pottery jar with a small foot, a bulbous body with the sides narrowing to a small shoulder, a single handle, a concave neck and a tall straight rim with a projecting rim around the base, one side of the body is indented and decorated with applied and incised features in the form of Bes, decorated with a buff-coloured slip.
Curator's comments: EA5095 is likely to be the Bes-vase published in the following (all publications incorrectly cite inv. no. 5696): S. Birch (1873) History of Ancient Pottery: Egyptian, Assyrian, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, p. 29 fig. 13 C. Guidotti (1983) 'Ipotesi di significato e tipologia dei vasi egizi di epoca tarda raffiguranti il dio Bes' Egitto e Vicino Oriente 6, p.45, fig. 15 D. Aston (2003) 'The dating of Late Period Bes vases' in Egyptian pottery: proceedings of the 1990 Pottery Symposium at the University of California, Berkeley, p.105
Published: Art and Afterlife in Ancient Egypt (Japan 1999-2000): No 141
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 1986 Jun-Oct, Carmarthen Museum, A son of Luxor's Sands
